blog.name: blookee
blog.title: The Fairy of BTS
blog.description: I'm a literal trash mammal so this will be an entire blog full of different BTS inspired writings. Fanfics, headcanons, drabbles, etc.

title: After Lie ⟪Yoonmin⟫
body:
Wattpad: Blookee

The backstage area was louder than normal. Everyone was hurrying in all directions, calling orders and barking demands to people who were across the large room from them. In the midst of the chaos that was the ‘behind the scenes’, Jimin stood in the middle of a huddle of makeup artists, outfit designers, and random workers that had made their way to the crowd that had began to form. The usual “The outfit looked amazing at that part”, “We need to touch up your makeup here”, “Your hair needs more support over here” lines were echoing through his ears as he desperately tried to tune them out. All of them were inspecting every inch of him. The him who was hot, sweaty, and wanting at least five feet to breathe after that number. He was panting with his heart thumping loudly, chest heaving as he tried to regain a normal breathing pattern and heart rate. Jimin just performed his heart out to the crowd in the stadium and really didn’t know if he’d be able to go back out. He was completely exhausted and t felt like all the energy he had at the beginning of the concert was absolutely sucked out of him. He was drained.. In all honesty, he wished he could disappear from that stadium and be back in the small studio the rapline hyungs used back in Seoul, specifically Yoongi’s.. But it was completely across the world from him  and it would be a while until he could go back to that calm, small place that he felt entirely safe and secure in.

“Park Jimin! Jimin-ssi!” The voice pulled him out of his thoughts that had slowly started to become more depressing and caused him to snap his head over in that direction, earning him the angered huffs and muttering of the makeup artists who was trying to quickly fix his makeup.

“Hyung..” Jimin’s face brightened in an instant as he saw Yoongi hustling over to him, a shocked expression painted across his face. “Is everything alright?” He asked when his hyung was finally standing in front of him after he somehow made his way through the crowd around Jimin.

“Jiminie.. Y- you–.. That–” The older member was stuttering and seemed to not know how to correctly form a sentence as he gazed at Jimin with wide eyes which seemed to be filled to the brim with awe. Yoongi took a moment to think to himself, closing his eyes. Jimin felt a small smile start to creep up his face as he stood watching his hyung who he’d never seen so worked up before open his eyes once more. “Jimin-ssi, that performance was the best that you’ve ever done. You blew everyone away.. The crowd, the workers and producers..” He paused and seemed to have been contemplating on continuing, “.. and me.. You did a very, very, good job. I’m so proud of you..  I hope you know that.” Yoongi had begun to smile with his eyes, showing his true emotions as he finished speaking.

Jimin suddenly felt a fluttery feeling in his chest, heat climbing its way up from his neck to his ears as he stood there, half not knowing what to say or how to react to the sudden kindness he was receiving from the member who is labeled as a ‘tsundere’.  “Hyung..–” He began but was quickly cut off by Yoongi who held up his hand, signaling Jimin to stop talking.

“Jimin-ssi, you need to get ready for your next song, so you should save your pretty voice and hurry to get ready.” He smirked at Jimin who was now the one feeling shocked, especially at the strange feeling that he had in his heart.

blog.name: luna-2020
blog.description: Just a random person who is a fan of bts.

body:
Getting this off my chest

I know this might be weird for my first post on here but I have to get this off my chest.

First off I listen to bts and I am the only one in my group of “friends” that do. So the other day they were talking and I was doing my own thing while listen in to bts, they came up to me and asked me “Why do you listen to bts, if you will never meet them or understand them. They are not even hot.” Now that ticked me off because to me it doesn’t matter if they are “hot” or not they put their all into making all of their listeners happy. I then answered them with a question of my own. “Why the hell do you listen to that rap music that is way to mature for someone like you to handle.” They were taken a back because I am a very patient person and I have never talked to them like that. Even though I didn’t show it I was pissed. I then kept going and said “I don’t listen to them if they are "hot” or not, now don’t get me wrong they are all attractive men, but they are more then just that they bring me happiness like other fans around the world. They perform like it is their last time they will ever be on stage. They went through struggles that you can’t even imagine, unlike the artists that you listen to. Bts are always greatful for everything they have, every time they get an award you can see it in their eyes, they are greatful. And their music is basically a story they are telling us, some happy and some sad. It doesn’t matter, even if some fans will never meet them, bts and their fans feel like a family. One of the best part about them is that they are all unique and different from one another, you can tell by the way they sing or rap. They all have the passion to make their fans happy, even if they are tired and hurt they will still be there to perform. Now I get that some peeple don’t like this type of genre but at least respect the fact that they climbed their way up the latter with their blood, sweat, and tears. They have made records that the guys you listen to will never make in a million years.“ Then I walked away.

In the end they were so pissed at me and have not talked to me since. So thats all I wanted to say.

title: Doors
body:
Summary: Charlie’s neighbor is a dick who’s always smoking without a shirt on even in the winter and watches her every time she leaves.

A/N: Please, please read the warnings.  Please, please, please do not hurt yourself.  “Don’t say you’re kidding if you’re not.  That’s the kind of talk that will make people stop paying attention to you.  Don’t cry wolf.”  Always here to talk or answer questions.

Warnings: This story is going to be dark.  Please be careful reading.  I’m talking bad words, rape, suicide, self-harm, abuse, violence, murder.  Seriously don’t read if any of that triggers you!

WC: 2,466

Masterlist   Part IV  Part VI

          It was always colder for Charlie on Thanksgiving, another day to remember what was missing.  It was also one of the few days throughout the year that she didn’t work, but she found herself unable to stay inside for long.  In the afternoon, after a turkey sandwich, she bundled herself up and headed to a park.  One glimpse told her that Yoongi was still gone.  She had been fearing the worse for him, that his brains were splattered in a pattern above his bed, or an array of pills were scattered around his body, or one stray match would explode the gas he had slowly leaked out to engulf him. The way he smoked, the last option might have been his way to go.  Any day now the smell would finally penetrate the door that she stopped by every morning and she would finally know that she was right, that she hadn’t helped at all, and that her neighbor—Yoongi—was dead.  She regretted now not taking his number as well; she knew no one who knew him, and she wasn’t going to call the police.

          Without physical proof, they could have no cause for forced entry.

          But she had found herself checking the obituaries and missing person reports anyway.  She did every day for work, anyway, to check up on old cases and be on the lookout for any new ones.

          She wasn’t really sure what she wanted to find, or what she expected.

          But when the sun was setting, she returned from her walk, and there he was, outside, smoking, and she was sure he saw her as she saw him, but, not wanting to break the spell, she said and did nothing except ascend the steps until she was in front of her door.  From there she could tell he really was back; his hair had aged three weeks, and had suddenly been bleached blonde, and he was fully dressed, but apart from that, his fingers went to his mouth and out in the same habitual manner.

          “Welcome back,” she said.

          “Thanks.”

          “Nice flannel.”

          “Thanks.”  She didn’t know what she had expected, but it wasn’t as painful as she thought it would be. He was far from forthcoming, but his eyes were responsive, and she could tell something had changed.

          “So did you actually get cold, or?”

          “Nah, I just tend to get dressed when I go out.”

          “Ah, right, for the best,” Charlie said. “Family?”

          “Hell no,” he said, a puff of smoke releasing them from him. “Just got back.”

          “Yeah,” she said, “where were you?”  She was closer to him now, and while the smoke repelled her, something in him had softened and was even inviting.  That was a possibility.  Or Charlie was just dying for anyone to be close to on this accursed holiday.  There was a power in shared loneliness.  She had learned that too late in some cases.

          “Well, when I told my sponsor what happened he insisted I check myself in.  So I was on a 72-hour suicide watch that turned into three weeks.”

          “Damn,” Charlie said, but her breath disappeared as he rolled up his flannel sleeves to show her all of his freshly made scars. The knowledge that he may not even feel her empowered her to softly run her fingers along them.  “I was really worried about you.”

          “Yeah?” he said, his fingers faltering.  He took a step away from her and stepped out his cigarette.  “You wanna come in for a cup of tea?”

          He opened the door, and for want of company or pure curiosity, Charlie followed him in.

          Helplessness was not going to beat him.  He had beaten these thoughts and feelings before, so this time shouldn’t be any harder.

          But it was.  Because every day was getting harder, because every day was added to the next.  He’d just lost it for a bit, for a few days.  That’s what he always allowed himself to believe.  And the meds would work better this time.  He already felt better.  Woozier, sure, and more dulled.  He had seen Charlie touch his arm, but he had felt nothing.

          He could feel the smoke against his throat, though, and he could feel the steaming tea on his tongue.  And he could see Charlie eyeing his apartment.  It wasn’t as clean as hers; he had more junk sitting around taking up room, but he had cleaned it when he had come home earlier that day.  A musty smell remained, but he could open windows when she left.

          She had taken off her coat, and he could see her collarbone above her sweater, and he followed her eyes around his apartment.

          “It’s messy, sorry,” he said, suddenly, surprisingly, embarrassed.

          “You just got back,” she said, “I’m just admiring your posters.”  Stylish The Black Knight Rises, Scott Pilgrim, Harry Potter, Kingsmen, Fargo, and Mad Max posters lined his walls, some peeling and tearing in the corners.  They had been up for three years, and he thought nothing of them now.

          “Mmm.  So you’re a social worker?” he said, and Charlie struggled to remember for a second giving him her card, but she also supposed he could have found that information out easily.

          “Yeah.”

          “Any good?”

          “Depends on what you mean by good,” she said, faltering again.  It wasn’t a question she had been asked before.

          “Do you help kids?”

          “Yes.  Those that I can.”

          “What do you mean?”

          “Sometimes they don’t want help.  Sometimes paperwork gets in the way.  Sometimes there doesn’t seem to be a solution.”

          “Work with any kids like me?” he said, nonchalantly sipping his tea.  She, of course, didn’t know what he meant.  Suicidal?  Smoker? Seemingly without a family or job? Of course.  But an obvious question wasn’t always so obvious.

          “What do you mean ‘like you’?”

          “You know,” he said, suddenly pulling down his sleeve again and running his fingers along his arm, the bumps in the road. And suddenly Charlie was angry.

          “Suicidal?  Yeah. If that’s what you mean, then yeah, I work with kids ‘like you.’”

          “And you help them liked you helped me?”

          “Yeah, sure,” she said, putting her cup down for fear her shaking would show, “when I can.”

          “How do you know what to say?”

          “You don’t.  Not really.  You go through a lot of training.  But sometimes that doesn’t work.  So then you just have to be good at reading people and improv from there.”

          “Are you good at reading people?”

          “I like to think so.  I’m good at listening, and that’s part, most, of it,” Charlie said, meeting Yoongi’s stare.  Neither of their eyes faltered beyond blinks.

          “Have you ever not saved someone?”

          “Yeah,” Charlie said casually, “of course.”

          “Can’t save ‘em all, huh?”

          “Right.”

          “What happened?”

          “I wasn’t ready.”

          “Not enough training, huh?”

          “No,” Charlie said, “plenty of training.  Not enough experience.”

          “Who was it?”

          “Just some girl.”

          “Just some girl?” Yoongi said, and he watched as Charlie’s eyes narrowed.  She may have training in reading people, but so did he.  His years on the streets had taught him plenty of ways to catch a liar.

          “Just some girl,” Charlie repeated.

          “Why don’t you just tell me?  I mean, we’ve come this far.”

          “This far?”

          “For fuck’s sake, Charlie, you almost saw me kill myself.  And, arguably, you saved me.  I probably wouldn’t be here if you hadn’t stopped me.  I don’t know about you, and I admit this is hard to admit, but, God, I feel like that connected us somehow.  Maybe that’s stupid, but.”  Charlie sighed and looked at the hallway, wondering if his room was around the corner, wondering what was hiding in his closet.

          “I’d better go,” she said, standing up.  Yoongi watched her but didn’t move.

          “Wow,” Yoongi barely muttered under his breath.

          “Look, I hate Thanksgiving, you know?  It makes me feel insanely sentimental.  My feelings are all fucked up.  And seeing you didn’t help.  I just mean,” she said, holding her hands out of front of her and trying to wipe out everything she just said, “I agree with you.  I haven’t stopped thinking about you since you got down off that wall, okay?  I know we’re connected, but I don’t really know what that means, and I’d rather figure that out before I resort to getting swept up in some emotional wave.  And I know that makes me sound like a complete ass,” she said, and was relieved to receive a smile, “but it’s instinct to push back against connections for me while simultaneously wanting them. That’s what my training’s been in, or something.”

          “Yeah,” Yoongi said, walking her to the door. “Just remember I may not feel you push, but I do have feelings.”

          “Shit,” Charlie said, turning back around outside to look at Yoongi.  He didn’t look like a Yoongi; not round or smooth at all; leaner and more scarred than he should be, than anyone should be.

          “Oh, hey, I’m only joking,” he said, grinning an irresistible grin that quickly dissolved when Charlie actually pushed him.

          “Don’t,” she said.

          “Whoa, shit, I didn’t mean actually push me.”

          “Don’t say that.”

          “What?  Gah,” Yoongi said as she pushed him lighter this time.

          “Don’t say you’re kidding if you’re not.  That’s the kind of talk that will make people stop paying attention to you.  Don’t cry wolf.”

          “Yeah, alright,” he said, “stop pushing me.”

          “Can you feel that?” Charlie said, her hand still on Yoongi’s shirt.

          “Yeah, no,” he said, picking her hand off of his chest.

          “It was my sister,” Charlie said, and Yoongi held onto her.  “When I was fourteen.  She’d been depressed for years, but my parents didn’t take her seriously.  She looked fine.  And then one day on our way home from school she jumped in front of the train.”

          “Shit,” Yoongi said, loosening his grip on her hand. “In front of you?”

          “Right in front of me.”

          “Damn,” Yoongi muttered, and then lamely her hand dropped from his. But before she could stick them back in her coat pockets, he wrapped his arms around her.  They felt like limp noodles, and he knew he had found his hands behind her, and he knew his face was pressed gently against her hair, but he felt so little, and he was afraid she would feel less.  But he was warmer than she expected, and her shoulders slackened, and she rested her forehead on his shoulder and took a deep breath.  But he smelled so much like smoke.  She pushed him gently away, coughing.

          “Shit, sorry,” Yoongi said.

          “It’s okay,” Charlie said in-between coughs. “My body just really hates smoke.”

          “I can’t imagine.”

          “Thanks for the tea,” Charlie said before slipping away.  And as soon as his door was shut, he slipped off his shoes and his shirt and slipped into bed, waiting to slip into sleep.

          She always slept with her phone beside her and her notifications on.  Not because anyone ever called—besides a few cases of drunk friends desperate for a ride in college—but because she had promised every friend she would always be available.  It wasn’t an empty promise; she meant what she said and said what she meant.  But haven’t not met anyone like her, most people did not take her seriously.  So when her phone buzzed, she immediately woke up, her heart racing and adrenaline pumping, ready to deal with an emergency.  The phone light temporarily blinded her, but then she read the time and the text:

          Unknown number: You up? (2:42AM)

          She had received plenty of random calls and texts; it was part of having a phone these days.  And she had received plenty of prank calls and texts; it was part of giving your phone number away to teenagers.  And she had received plenty of “booty calls” and unsolicited inappropriate pictures; it was part of being a woman.  But her sense that someone could be in danger was too strong, so she had to reply.

           Charlie: Who is this? (2:44AM)

           …

           Unknown number: Ouch.  Yoongi (2:45AM)

Charlie sat up in bed.

           Charlie: Oh shit, sorry, didn’t have your number (2:45AM)

           Yoongi: Ah yeah (2:45AM)

           Yoongi: So I guess you’re up. (2:46AM)

           Charlie: Am now (2:46AM)

           Yoongi: Did I wake you up?? (2:46AM)

           Charlie: Yeah (2:47AM)

           Yoongi: Shit, sorry, go back to sleep. (2:47AM)

           Charlie: What’s up? (2:47AM)

           Yoongi: Nah, nothing (2:47AM)

           Charlie: Right.  Why you still awake? (2:48AM)

           Yoongi: Can’t sleep (2:49AM)

Charlie turned on her lamp.  Ever additional beam of light made her want to close her eyes more.

           Charlie: You okay? (2:49AM)

           Yoongi: Yeah (2:50AM)

           Charlie: Convincing (2:50AM)

           Yoongi: Ha (2:50AM)

           Charlie: Want to come talk about it? (2:52AM)

           Yoongi: Nah, no worries (2:52AM)

           Charlie: Don’t make me come push you (2:52AM)

           Yoongi: Ha. Don’t you have work in the morning? (2:53AM)

           Charlie, just come over. I’ll unlock the door. (2:54AM)

Charlie got out of bed, shuffling down the hall and to the front door.  She flicked on the outside light and undid the latch.  Then she leaned against the counter and closed her eyes.  Her phone buzzed again.

           Yoongi: Ok (2:58AM)

Charlie opened the door, and there he was, minus his shoes and shirt again, but this seemed to be how she recognized him best.  She motioned for him to come in and then shut and locked the door behind him.  She shuffled back down the hall, but at the doorway turned around as he stood in the kitchen.

           “Come on,” she whispered, her eyes half open.  He followed but found himself suddenly in an odd position.  He had not expected her to be up.  Or to respond.  Or to invite him over.  Or to care. He stood again at her bedroom door and watched her get back into bed.

           “Come on,” she said, a little exasperated, patting the bed beside her. But he lingered for a moment, the glow of her lamp revealing a patchwork quilt of various flowers.  Two plants sat in her window sill, and a picture he couldn’t make out sat on her dresser.  She had already slid down under the covers and was reaching to turn out the light, so he hurried—while still tiptoeing like an idiot—to climb into bed beside her. He could tell it was warmer, and the smell of lavender seemed to surround him.

           “Two rules,” he heard Charlie whisper, and he lay on his side to look at her in the dark.  “No touching, and no getting upset if I fall asleep.”

           “Yeah, sure,” he said, feeling like he was at a sleepover at the cool kid’s house. Now that he was here, he was afraid to say or do anything for fear of being kicked out.  So he didn’t, and Charlie didn’t seem to care, as she was soon asleep.

          It was always colder for Charlie on Thanksgiving, another day to remember what was missing.  It was also one of the few days throughout the year that she didn’t work, but she found herself unable to stay inside for long.  In the afternoon, after a turkey sandwich, she bundled herself up and headed to a park.  One glimpse told her that Yoongi was still gone.  She had been fearing the worse for him, that his brains were splattered in a pattern above his bed, or an array of pills were scattered around his body, or one stray match would explode the gas he had slowly leaked out to engulf him. The way he smoked, the last option might have been his way to go.  Any day now the smell would finally penetrate the door that she stopped by every morning and she would finally know that she was right, that she hadn’t helped at all, and that her neighbor—Yoongi—was dead.  She regretted now not taking his number as well; she knew no one who knew him, and she wasn’t going to call the police.

Masterlist   Part IV  Part VI

          It was always colder for Charlie on Thanksgiving, another day to remember what was missing.  It was also one of the few days throughout the year that she didn’t work, but she found herself unable to stay inside for long.  In the afternoon, after a turkey sandwich, she bundled herself up and headed to a park.  One glimpse told her that Yoongi was still gone.  She had been fearing the worse for him, that his brains were splattered in a pattern above his bed, or an array of pills were scattered around his body, or one stray match would explode the gas he had slowly leaked out to engulf him. [[MORE]]

          Without physical proof, they could have no cause for forced entry.

          But she had found herself checking the obituaries and missing person reports anyway.  She did every day for work, anyway, to check up on old cases and be on the lookout for any new ones.

          She wasn’t really sure what she wanted to find, or what she expected.

          But when the sun was setting, she returned from her walk, and there he was, outside, smoking, and she was sure he saw her as she saw him, but, not wanting to break the spell, she said and did nothing except ascend the steps until she was in front of her door.  From there she could tell he really was back; his hair had aged three weeks, and had suddenly been bleached blonde, and he was fully dressed, but apart from that, his fingers went to his mouth and out in the same habitual manner.

          “Welcome back,” she said.

          “Thanks.”

          “Nice flannel.”

          “Thanks.”  She didn’t know what she had expected, but it wasn’t as painful as she thought it would be. He was far from forthcoming, but his eyes were responsive, and she could tell something had changed.

          “So did you actually get cold, or?”

          “Nah, I just tend to get dressed when I go out.”

          “Ah, right, for the best,” Charlie said. “Family?”

          “Hell no,” he said, a puff of smoke releasing them from him. “Just got back.”

          “Yeah,” she said, “where were you?”  She was closer to him now, and while the smoke repelled her, something in him had softened and was even inviting.  That was a possibility.  Or Charlie was just dying for anyone to be close to on this accursed holiday.  There was a power in shared loneliness.  She had learned that too late in some cases.

          “Well, when I told my sponsor what happened he insisted I check myself in.  So I was on a 72-hour suicide watch that turned into three weeks.”

          “Damn,” Charlie said, but her breath disappeared as he rolled up his flannel sleeves to show her all of his freshly made scars. The knowledge that he may not even feel her empowered her to softly run her fingers along them.  “I was really worried about you.”

          “Yeah?” he said, his fingers faltering.  He took a step away from her and stepped out his cigarette.  “You wanna come in for a cup of tea?”

          He opened the door, and for want of company or pure curiosity, Charlie followed him in.

          Helplessness was not going to beat him.  He had beaten these thoughts and feelings before, so this time shouldn’t be any harder.

          But it was.  Because every day was getting harder, because every day was added to the next.  He’d just lost it for a bit, for a few days.  That’s what he always allowed himself to believe.  And the meds would work better this time.  He already felt better.  Woozier, sure, and more dulled.  He had seen Charlie touch his arm, but he had felt nothing.

          He could feel the smoke against his throat, though, and he could feel the steaming tea on his tongue.  And he could see Charlie eyeing his apartment.  It wasn’t as clean as hers; he had more junk sitting around taking up room, but he had cleaned it when he had come home earlier that day.  A musty smell remained, but he could open windows when she left.

          She had taken off her coat, and he could see her collarbone above her sweater, and he followed her eyes around his apartment.

          “It’s messy, sorry,” he said, suddenly, surprisingly, embarrassed.

          “You just got back,” she said, “I’m just admiring your posters.”  Stylish The Black Knight Rises, Scott Pilgrim, Harry Potter, Kingsmen, Fargo, and Mad Max posters lined his walls, some peeling and tearing in the corners.  They had been up for three years, and he thought nothing of them now.

          “Mmm.  So you’re a social worker?” he said, and Charlie struggled to remember for a second giving him her card, but she also supposed he could have found that information out easily.

          “Yeah.”

          “Any good?”

          “Depends on what you mean by good,” she said, faltering again.  It wasn’t a question she had been asked before.

          “Do you help kids?”

          “Yes.  Those that I can.”

          “What do you mean?”

          “Sometimes they don’t want help.  Sometimes paperwork gets in the way.  Sometimes there doesn’t seem to be a solution.”

          “Work with any kids like me?” he said, nonchalantly sipping his tea.  She, of course, didn’t know what he meant.  Suicidal?  Smoker? Seemingly without a family or job? Of course.  But an obvious question wasn’t always so obvious.

          “What do you mean ‘like you’?”

          “You know,” he said, suddenly pulling down his sleeve again and running his fingers along his arm, the bumps in the road. And suddenly Charlie was angry.

          “Suicidal?  Yeah. If that’s what you mean, then yeah, I work with kids ‘like you.’”

          “And you help them liked you helped me?”

          “Yeah, sure,” she said, putting her cup down for fear her shaking would show, “when I can.”

          “How do you know what to say?”

          “You don’t.  Not really.  You go through a lot of training.  But sometimes that doesn’t work.  So then you just have to be good at reading people and improv from there.”

          “Are you good at reading people?”

          “I like to think so.  I’m good at listening, and that’s part, most, of it,” Charlie said, meeting Yoongi’s stare.  Neither of their eyes faltered beyond blinks.

          “Have you ever not saved someone?”

          “Yeah,” Charlie said casually, “of course.”

          “Can’t save ‘em all, huh?”

          “Right.”

          “What happened?”

          “I wasn’t ready.”

          “Not enough training, huh?”

          “No,” Charlie said, “plenty of training.  Not enough experience.”

          “Who was it?”

          “Just some girl.”

          “Just some girl?” Yoongi said, and he watched as Charlie’s eyes narrowed.  She may have training in reading people, but so did he.  His years on the streets had taught him plenty of ways to catch a liar.

          “Just some girl,” Charlie repeated.

          “Why don’t you just tell me?  I mean, we’ve come this far.”

          “This far?”

          “For fuck’s sake, Charlie, you almost saw me kill myself.  And, arguably, you saved me.  I probably wouldn’t be here if you hadn’t stopped me.  I don’t know about you, and I admit this is hard to admit, but, God, I feel like that connected us somehow.  Maybe that’s stupid, but.”  Charlie sighed and looked at the hallway, wondering if his room was around the corner, wondering what was hiding in his closet.

          “I’d better go,” she said, standing up.  Yoongi watched her but didn’t move.

          “Wow,” Yoongi barely muttered under his breath.

          “Look, I hate Thanksgiving, you know?  It makes me feel insanely sentimental.  My feelings are all fucked up.  And seeing you didn’t help.  I just mean,” she said, holding her hands out of front of her and trying to wipe out everything she just said, “I agree with you.  I haven’t stopped thinking about you since you got down off that wall, okay?  I know we’re connected, but I don’t really know what that means, and I’d rather figure that out before I resort to getting swept up in some emotional wave.  And I know that makes me sound like a complete ass,” she said, and was relieved to receive a smile, “but it’s instinct to push back against connections for me while simultaneously wanting them. That’s what my training’s been in, or something.”

          “Yeah,” Yoongi said, walking her to the door. “Just remember I may not feel you push, but I do have feelings.”

          “Shit,” Charlie said, turning back around outside to look at Yoongi.  He didn’t look like a Yoongi; not round or smooth at all; leaner and more scarred than he should be, than anyone should be.

          “Oh, hey, I’m only joking,” he said, grinning an irresistible grin that quickly dissolved when Charlie actually pushed him.

          “Don’t,” she said.

          “Whoa, shit, I didn’t mean actually push me.”

          “Don’t say that.”

          “What?  Gah,” Yoongi said as she pushed him lighter this time.

          “Don’t say you’re kidding if you’re not.  That’s the kind of talk that will make people stop paying attention to you.  Don’t cry wolf.”

          “Yeah, alright,” he said, “stop pushing me.”

          “Can you feel that?” Charlie said, her hand still on Yoongi’s shirt.

          “Yeah, no,” he said, picking her hand off of his chest.

          “It was my sister,” Charlie said, and Yoongi held onto her.  “When I was fourteen.  She’d been depressed for years, but my parents didn’t take her seriously.  She looked fine.  And then one day on our way home from school she jumped in front of the train.”

          “Shit,” Yoongi said, loosening his grip on her hand. “In front of you?”

          “Right in front of me.”

          “Damn,” Yoongi muttered, and then lamely her hand dropped from his. But before she could stick them back in her coat pockets, he wrapped his arms around her.  They felt like limp noodles, and he knew he had found his hands behind her, and he knew his face was pressed gently against her hair, but he felt so little, and he was afraid she would feel less.  But he was warmer than she expected, and her shoulders slackened, and she rested her forehead on his shoulder and took a deep breath.  But he smelled so much like smoke.  She pushed him gently away, coughing.

          “Shit, sorry,” Yoongi said.

          “It’s okay,” Charlie said in-between coughs. “My body just really hates smoke.”

          “I can’t imagine.”

          “Thanks for the tea,” Charlie said before slipping away.  And as soon as his door was shut, he slipped off his shoes and his shirt and slipped into bed, waiting to slip into sleep.

          She always slept with her phone beside her and her notifications on.  Not because anyone ever called—besides a few cases of drunk friends desperate for a ride in college—but because she had promised every friend she would always be available.  It wasn’t an empty promise; she meant what she said and said what she meant.  But haven’t not met anyone like her, most people did not take her seriously.  So when her phone buzzed, she immediately woke up, her heart racing and adrenaline pumping, ready to deal with an emergency.  The phone light temporarily blinded her, but then she read the time and the text:

          Unknown number: You up? (2:42AM)

          She had received plenty of random calls and texts; it was part of having a phone these days.  And she had received plenty of prank calls and texts; it was part of giving your phone number away to teenagers.  And she had received plenty of “booty calls” and unsolicited inappropriate pictures; it was part of being a woman.  But her sense that someone could be in danger was too strong, so she had to reply.

           Charlie: Who is this? (2:44AM)

           …

           Unknown number: Ouch.  Yoongi (2:45AM)

Charlie sat up in bed.

           Charlie: Oh shit, sorry, didn’t have your number (2:45AM)

           Yoongi: Ah yeah (2:45AM)

           Yoongi: So I guess you’re up. (2:46AM)

           Charlie: Am now (2:46AM)

           Yoongi: Did I wake you up?? (2:46AM)

           Charlie: Yeah (2:47AM)

           Yoongi: Shit, sorry, go back to sleep. (2:47AM)

           Charlie: What’s up? (2:47AM)

           Yoongi: Nah, nothing (2:47AM)

           Charlie: Right.  Why you still awake? (2:48AM)

           Yoongi: Can’t sleep (2:49AM)

Charlie turned on her lamp.  Ever additional beam of light made her want to close her eyes more.

           Charlie: You okay? (2:49AM)

           Yoongi: Yeah (2:50AM)

           Charlie: Convincing (2:50AM)

           Yoongi: Ha (2:50AM)

           Charlie: Want to come talk about it? (2:52AM)

           Yoongi: Nah, no worries (2:52AM)

           Charlie: Don’t make me come push you (2:52AM)

           Yoongi: Ha. Don’t you have work in the morning? (2:53AM)

           Charlie, just come over. I’ll unlock the door. (2:54AM)

Charlie got out of bed, shuffling down the hall and to the front door.  She flicked on the outside light and undid the latch.  Then she leaned against the counter and closed her eyes.  Her phone buzzed again.

           Yoongi: Ok (2:58AM)

Charlie opened the door, and there he was, minus his shoes and shirt again, but this seemed to be how she recognized him best.  She motioned for him to come in and then shut and locked the door behind him.  She shuffled back down the hall, but at the doorway turned around as he stood in the kitchen.

           “Come on,” she whispered, her eyes half open.  He followed but found himself suddenly in an odd position.  He had not expected her to be up.  Or to respond.  Or to invite him over.  Or to care. He stood again at her bedroom door and watched her get back into bed.

           “Come on,” she said, a little exasperated, patting the bed beside her. But he lingered for a moment, the glow of her lamp revealing a patchwork quilt of various flowers.  Two plants sat in her window sill, and a picture he couldn’t make out sat on her dresser.  She had already slid down under the covers and was reaching to turn out the light, so he hurried—while still tiptoeing like an idiot—to climb into bed beside her. He could tell it was warmer, and the smell of lavender seemed to surround him.

           “Two rules,” he heard Charlie whisper, and he lay on his side to look at her in the dark.  “No touching, and no getting upset if I fall asleep.”

           “Yeah, sure,” he said, feeling like he was at a sleepover at the cool kid’s house. Now that he was here, he was afraid to say or do anything for fear of being kicked out.  So he didn’t, and Charlie didn’t seem to care, as she was soon asleep.

The way he smoked, the last option might have been his way to go.  Any day now the smell would finally penetrate the door that she stopped by every morning and she would finally know that she was right, that she hadn’t helped at all, and that her neighbor—Yoongi—was dead.  She regretted now not taking his number as well; she knew no one who knew him, and she wasn’t going to call the police.

          Without physical proof, they could have no cause for forced entry.

          But she had found herself checking the obituaries and missing person reports anyway.  She did every day for work, anyway, to check up on old cases and be on the lookout for any new ones.

          She wasn’t really sure what she wanted to find, or what she expected.

          But when the sun was setting, she returned from her walk, and there he was, outside, smoking, and she was sure he saw her as she saw him, but, not wanting to break the spell, she said and did nothing except ascend the steps until she was in front of her door.  From there she could tell he really was back; his hair had aged three weeks, and had suddenly been bleached blonde, and he was fully dressed, but apart from that, his fingers went to his mouth and out in the same habitual manner.

          “Welcome back,” she said.

          “Thanks.”

          “Nice flannel.”

          “Thanks.”  She didn’t know what she had expected, but it wasn’t as painful as she thought it would be. He was far from forthcoming, but his eyes were responsive, and she could tell something had changed.

          “So did you actually get cold, or?”

          “Nah, I just tend to get dressed when I go out.”

          “Ah, right, for the best,” Charlie said. “Family?”

          “Hell no,” he said, a puff of smoke releasing them from him. “Just got back.”

          “Yeah,” she said, “where were you?”  She was closer to him now, and while the smoke repelled her, something in him had softened and was even inviting.  That was a possibility.  Or Charlie was just dying for anyone to be close to on this accursed holiday.  There was a power in shared loneliness.  She had learned that too late in some cases.

          “Well, when I told my sponsor what happened he insisted I check myself in.  So I was on a 72-hour suicide watch that turned into three weeks.”

          “Damn,” Charlie said, but her breath disappeared as he rolled up his flannel sleeves to show her all of his freshly made scars. The knowledge that he may not even feel her empowered her to softly run her fingers along them.  “I was really worried about you.”

          “Yeah?” he said, his fingers faltering.  He took a step away from her and stepped out his cigarette.  “You wanna come in for a cup of tea?”

          He opened the door, and for want of company or pure curiosity, Charlie followed him in.

          Helplessness was not going to beat him.  He had beaten these thoughts and feelings before, so this time shouldn’t be any harder.

          But it was.  Because every day was getting harder, because every day was added to the next.  He’d just lost it for a bit, for a few days.  That’s what he always allowed himself to believe.  And the meds would work better this time.  He already felt better.  Woozier, sure, and more dulled.  He had seen Charlie touch his arm, but he had felt nothing.

          He could feel the smoke against his throat, though, and he could feel the steaming tea on his tongue.  And he could see Charlie eyeing his apartment.  It wasn’t as clean as hers; he had more junk sitting around taking up room, but he had cleaned it when he had come home earlier that day.  A musty smell remained, but he could open windows when she left.

          She had taken off her coat, and he could see her collarbone above her sweater, and he followed her eyes around his apartment.

          “It’s messy, sorry,” he said, suddenly, surprisingly, embarrassed.

          “You just got back,” she said, “I’m just admiring your posters.”  Stylish The Black Knight Rises, Scott Pilgrim, Harry Potter, Kingsmen, Fargo, and Mad Max posters lined his walls, some peeling and tearing in the corners.  They had been up for three years, and he thought nothing of them now.

          “Mmm.  So you’re a social worker?” he said, and Charlie struggled to remember for a second giving him her card, but she also supposed he could have found that information out easily.

          “Yeah.”

          “Any good?”

          “Depends on what you mean by good,” she said, faltering again.  It wasn’t a question she had been asked before.

          “Do you help kids?”

          “Yes.  Those that I can.”

          “What do you mean ‘like you’?”

          “You know,” he said, suddenly pulling down his sleeve again and running his fingers along his arm, the bumps in the road. And suddenly Charlie was angry.

          “Suicidal?  Yeah. If that’s what you mean, then yeah, I work with kids ‘like you.’”

          “And you help them liked you helped me?”

          “Yeah, sure,” she said, putting her cup down for fear her shaking would show, “when I can.”

          “How do you know what to say?”

          “I like to think so.  I’m good at listening, and that’s part, most, of it,” Charlie said, meeting Yoongi’s stare.  Neither of their eyes faltered beyond blinks.

That’s what my training’s been in, or something.”

          “Yeah,” Yoongi said, walking her to the door. “Just remember I may not feel you push, but I do have feelings.”

          “Shit,” Yoongi said, loosening his grip on her hand. “In front of you?”
